verses.text: Better is virtue that stands alone than offspring without it; for virtue is immortal, and it is recognized both by God and by men.
verses.comment: Here virtue is elevated above lineage, echoing teachings on the enduring value of righteousness. The immortal nature of virtue foreshadows the biblical doctrine of eternal reward for the righteous, aligning with spiritual interpretations in the New Testament (see Matt. 5:8).

verses.text: When virtue is present, people imitate it; and when it has been taken away, they eagerly seek it. In life, virtue leads to victory and in death, it leaves an enduring remembrance.
verses.comment: The recognition and imitation of virtue mirrors Paul's exhortations to imitate Christ and the saints (1 Cor. 11:1). The enduring remembrance is reminiscent of biblical references to the memorial of the righteous (Luke 1:50).

verses.text: But the numerous families of the ungodly shall not flourish, nor will illegitimate shoots take root, nor will they put down secure foundations.
verses.comment: This verse contrasts the security of the righteous with the instability of the wicked; a theme echoed in Jesus' teaching about the house built upon rock (Matt. 7:24-27).

verses.text: For even if they grow rich for a time, in the end they will be unregarded and their offshoots will be cursed and their roots will be forgotten.
verses.comment: The temporary prosperity of the ungodly is a recurring biblical motif, suggesting that eternal security is only found in righteousness, not in worldly success.

verses.text: For they bear fruit that is worthless, which will not ripen or be profitable, and will be consumed before harvest.
verses.comment: This agricultural imagery recalls Jesus’ parable of the sower and teaching on good fruit (Matt. 7:17-19), pointing to the spiritual barrenness of the unrighteous.

verses.text: For children born of unlawful unions bear witness to evil, against their parents when examined.
verses.comment: The consequences of sin impacting descendants is a concept seen throughout Scripture (Ex. 20:5), but it should not be misunderstood as personal condemnation—rather, the text emphasizes the seriousness of moral choices.

verses.text: But the righteous, though they die early, shall be at rest.
verses.comment: Rest for the righteous calls to mind the ‘sleep in Christ’ (1 Thess. 4:14), indicating hope of life after death and connection to the doctrine of the communion of saints.

verses.text: For old age is not honored by long life, nor measured by the number of years;
verses.comment: True honor before God is found in holiness rather than mere longevity—a theme that encourages spiritual rather than worldly priorities (Phil. 1:21).

verses.text: but understanding is gray hair for men, and a blameless life is ripe old age.
verses.comment: Wisdom and blamelessness are portrayed as spiritual maturity, linking to Paul's exhortation for believers to grow in wisdom (Col. 1:9-10).

verses.text: He pleased God and was beloved by Him; living among sinners, he was taken up.
verses.comment: This refers to the 'taking up' or assumption, a sign of divine favor found in Enoch’s story. The concept of translation prefigures Christian hope for union with God.

verses.text: He was removed so that evil might not change his understanding or deceit beguile his soul.
verses.comment: The preservation of the righteous from evil is seen as divine protection, a truth seen in Christ’s own prayers for His disciples (John 17:15).

verses.text: For the fascination of wickedness obscures what is good, and the wantonness of desire perverts an innocent mind.
verses.comment: This verse highlights the spiritual danger of unchecked desire, a theme central to both Old and New Testament calls to holiness (Gal. 5:19-21).

verses.text: Being perfected in a short time, he fulfilled long years; for his soul was pleasing to the Lord.
verses.comment: God’s measure of perfection is not in time but faithfulness, reflecting Jesus’ words in Matt. 20:16 about the last being first.

verses.text: Therefore He hurried him out of the midst of wickedness. But the people see it and do not understand, nor do they take such things to heart:
verses.comment: God’s mysterious purposes are sometimes misunderstood; the inability to perceive divine action is a recurring theme, including in Jesus’ ministry.

verses.text: that God’s grace and mercy are with His chosen, and care for His holy ones.
verses.comment: Grace and mercy to the sanctified connects to New Testament themes of election and predestination, underlying the reality of a divinely guarded people.

verses.text: But the righteous who die will condemn the ungodly who live long lives, and youth quickly perfected will judge the many years of the aged unrighteous.
verses.comment: True judgement is based on righteousness, not age or longevity. The motif of the righteous judging the wicked prefigures eschatological judgment (1 Cor. 6:2).

verses.text: For the unrighteous will see the end of the wise and will not understand what the Lord has purposed concerning them, nor why He has kept them safe.
verses.comment: God’s providence and mysterious plan are often hidden from the worldly-minded, a theme central to Christ’s parables and teachings (Matt. 13:13).

verses.text: They will look upon him and mock, but the Lord will laugh them to scorn.
verses.comment: Divine reversal—those who mock the righteous are ultimately subject to God's judgment. This foreshadows Christ’s vindication over those who scorned Him (Luke 23:35-43).

verses.text: Afterward they will be a dishonored corpse and an everlasting disgrace among the dead;
verses.comment: Everlasting shame is used here to contrast eternal reward. The theme is reflected in Jesus’ words about resurrection of those to life and those to judgment (John 5:28-29).

verses.text: for He will cast them down speechless, and pull them from the foundations. They will be utterly wasted; and they will be in sorrow, and their memory will perish.
verses.comment: Judgment and erasure of memory for the wicked is part of biblical teaching on ultimate justice, encouraging perseverance in virtue and living as part of the holy people of God.
